entry.title: Combined summary - Dynamic MaxBlockSize - 3 Byte Solution
entry.summary: A recent email thread on the bitcoin-dev mailing list discussed the proposal of Dynamic MaxBlockSize (DMBS) - 3 Byte Solution, which aims to address the block size issue in a dynamic and efficient manner. The DMBS proposal suggests adding a 3-byte variable factor to the white space in the current block to evaluate the market-driven demand and adjust the block size dynamically. The ruleset for this proposal evaluates to YES or NO, depending on whether there is increased system pressure or decreased market pressure. The approach limits changes to one change every three hours if there is a market pressure "STATE" occurring. There are divided opinions about the viability of the proposed solution.While one member of the group has NACKed the proposal due to his belief that Lightning and SegWit have already solved the problem of block size, another member disagrees. Although Segwit has increased the possibilities of using space more efficiently, off-chain constructions like channel factories are yet to be tested and proved effective. Therefore, claiming that we don't need to deal with the block size issue anymore would be bold and unjustified.One participant in the thread advocates keeping the block size low for now but leaving room for increasing it in the future when necessary via an extension block. They argue that even with Lightning and SegWit, there would still be too many channel open and closes to handle millions of users without transaction fees skyrocketing. Another participant raises concerns about the impact of a reorg on validation and questions whether the current block can accommodate the proposed DMBS solution. However, the proposal aims to provide a middle ground solution to scale dynamically without compromising existing security or changing existing rulesets.The conversation between Hampus Sjöberg and Luke pertains to the current block size of Bitcoin which is 1 MB. While Hampus believes that the average block size will go down when exchanges start using Lightning or Liquid, Luke disagrees as long as spam continues to pad blocks full. When discussing the possibility of increasing the block size, Hampus suggests that it should only be done through a hard fork, to which Luke points out that there may not be a consensus for a blocksize increase hardfork due to past malicious attempts. They also discussed the use of extension blocks, with Hampus arguing that they are unreasonably convoluted while Luke argues that they are still a softfork since old nodes can still follow the mainchain. Ultimately, they both agree that any changes made should have consensus in order to maintain the stability and security of Bitcoin.Overall, the discussions on the bitcoin-dev mailing list highlight the complex considerations involved in addressing block size and scaling issues in a way that maintains security, decentralization, and existing rulesets while also meeting market demand. The proposed solution provides a suitable middle ground and addresses concerns dynamically without compromising existing security. However, it remains unclear if the current block can accommodate the 3-byte variable. The author of the proposal seeks feedback from the community on the viability of the solution and its effectiveness in solving the scaling issue. While there are divided opinions on whether or not the proposed solution is worth pursuing, it is clear that any changes made should have consensus in order to maintain the stability and security of Bitcoin.
